video.title: Metal Gear Solid Δ: Snake Eater | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
Once upon a time in the magical world of Japan, 
there was a plucky little game developer named

Hideo Kojima who made a little action game 
called Metal Gear that had a relatively

stock action movie plot about a knockoff of 
Snake Plissken from Escape From New York with

the phallic undertones of their name made 
considerably less subtle fighting an evil,

culturally ambiguous terrorist group. A game so 
generic it flat-out used painted-over stills from

&#39;80s action movies for the key art, and when it 
came time to name the big boss villain of the

game, little Hideo Kojima thought, &quot;Well, 
no need to put too much thought into it;

let&#39;s just call him Big Boss because that&#39;s what 
he is. I mean, it&#39;s not like this is going to

turn into the franchise that defines my entire 
fucking career.&quot; Seventeen years and multiple

anomalously successful sequels later, a wiser, 
less impulsive 2004 Hideo Kojima suddenly decides

it&#39;s important to make an elaborate prequel set in 
the Cold War with the main purpose of explaining

why the dude was called Big Boss and why it&#39;s 
actually very sensible that he was called that,

and there&#39;s a heart-wrenching story attached, 
so don&#39;t you feel bad for taking the piss?

Er, you know, Hideo, most people would have just 
retconned it. &quot;NO. NO RETCONS. EVERYTHING IS CANON

FOREVER. EVEN THAT REALLY STUPID OWL PUZZLE IN 
METAL GEAR 2.&quot; Right you are, Kojima, you mad,

mad, bastard. And now, here in 2025, we have Metal 
Gear Solid Delta, a ground-up remaster of the

original Metal Gear Solid 3, which Hideo himself 
technically isn&#39;t involved in, but it follows the

strict definition of remaster in that it&#39;s pretty 
much just a layering of HD graphics on top of the

original, so we can quite justifiably give Hideo 
Kojima another nostalgic kick in his mad, mad,

bollocks for it. Straight remaster is probably 
the best way Konami could&#39;ve played it, frankly,

as it&#39;s been made perfectly clear over and over 
again that nobody who currently works there knows

what the fuck they&#39;re doing. Actually, I gather 
there have been some core gameplay improvements,

and knowing that frankly boggles my mind as 
I wonder how godawful they must have been the

first time around if this constitutes &quot;improved.&quot; 
I never played the original MGS3, surprisingly,

considering I played the shit out of 1, 2, and 
4. I guess my feeling was that if the game could

offer no material for use in my Otacon Mpreg 
fan fiction empire, I just didn&#39;t wanna know.

I knew what happens in MGS3, having watched 
video playthroughs with my brow permanently

creased in the typical Kojima frown of aroused 
bafflement and occasionally pausing to run to

the toilet due to the subconscious influence of 
the graphics&#39; omnipresent cloudy piss filter.

The protagonist is Snake of the non-solid 
variety—grizzled, gun-liking action man who

is the fully grown adopted bitch boy of someone 
called The Boss. As in, that isn&#39;t a nickname;

that&#39;s their official title, presumably to 
differentiate her from Bruce Springsteen. We&#39;re

reliably informed that The Boss is the greatest 
soldier in the history of ever, but in real terms,

she&#39;s essentially the archetypal Hideo Kojima 
character: a beautiful female victim of various

forms of horrifying abuse who, at one point, 
gets her tits out for no particular reason

and who communicates exclusively in verbose, 
broadly philosophical lectures. &quot;Hey, The Boss,

do you want a cup of tea?&quot; &quot;What need has 
a soldier of tea? To a soldier, all that

matters is the mission. Custard creams have no 
place on the battlefield.&quot; I didn&#39;t even bring

up the custard creams, you mad bint. Oh, and she 
was probably a child soldier. Because who the fuck

wasn&#39;t in this series? I guess Otacon wasn&#39;t. But 
not for want of trying, am I right, lore experts?

Anyway, The Boss defects to the Soviet Union and 
teams up with a dude fermenting a coup against

the Russian premier but who is also unrelatedly a 
giant, bulletproof, electric man (just roll with

it, alright?), and Snake is sent in alone to 
foil their schemes and assassinate him and The

Boss by going all third-person stealth action 
on their inexplicably superpowered tits. So,

as I hinted earlier, the basic gameplay of Metal 
Gear Solid controls like two greasy dog penises.

Snake runs like he&#39;s trying to catch a bus 
that hasn&#39;t started moving yet and he doesn&#39;t

particularly want to catch; if he gets knocked 
down, he goes into prone state and has to press

the crouch button twice to get back up and start 
hitting things again, but if he presses it for

two too many nanoseconds, he plops right back down 
into prone like he&#39;s decided he hasn&#39;t quite given

up looking for his contact lens. When you grab a 
dude, the merest touch or release of a button or

stick is the difference between letting him go, 
slitting his throat, or pitching him headfirst

into a curb. All the same, I do get a pleasing 
sense of nostalgia playing a combat system from

back before such things were so tiresomely 
standardized. See, I get the sense Hideo felt

the series was in a bit of a rut after MGS2—top 
down, soliton radar, boss fights with weirdos,

lots of banging on about nanomachines—and took 
the opportunity of a prequel to experiment a bit.

As such, MGS3 is a game of ideas. Some of which 
are good. Iconic, even. Like the camouflage system

or the prolonged sniping duel against The End 
in the middle of the game, counterintuitively.

And then there the are other ideas. Like the 
healing system. A classic example of trying to

add realism to the eternally ridiculous concept 
of eating a box of health to regrow all your lost

limbs and ending up with a clunky set of hoops 
to jump through like we&#39;re stuck in our local

hospital&#39;s automated answering service. Being a 
game of ideas, MGS3 is full of memorable moments,

but it doesn&#39;t string together well into a 
cohesive whole. In contrast to 1 and 2 that took

place in single large facilities, encouraging 
you to get a sense for your environment,

3 is more a linear sequence of small encounters, 
dipping its toes into one new gameplay mechanic

after another—a rail shooting segment here, 
an escort quest there—but rarely makes the

most of anything. And as for the story, Jesus 
H. Christina Aguilera, trying to take that as

a cohesive whole is like trying to train two 
dolphins to gather together a load of bars

of wet soap. The cutscenes are full of bizarre 
interactions and conversations that go nowhere.

Between characters who we are always told are 
world-class experts in their fields but whose

actions provide very little evidence for that. 
Like the lady who&#39;s ostensibly a master seductress

whose main go-to strategy is to unzip her top 
down to her pubes and jiggle about a bit. And

of course, there&#39;s plenty of Hideo&#39;s trademark 
glaring tonal shifts. I&#39;m thinking of the bit

where giant bulletproof electric man is torturing 
Snake in an actually genuinely upsetting way and

suddenly goes, &quot;You&#39;ll never find out that my 
secret treasure is downstairs in room B7 in a

safe locked with the combination 9-9-7-4! So 
stop thinking you will!&quot; At which point one

can only laugh. &quot;Yes, thank you, Yahtz. Consider 
our nostalgic memories thoroughly urinated on,

but if we could get back to the subject of what 
the remake adds to the original?&quot; Er. Bugger all,

really. As I say, it&#39;s more or less a straight 
remaster copy-paste situation, so what you&#39;re

getting is no piss filter, the wonderful 
opportunity to pay full price for it again,

and all the characters can make more realistic 
facial expressions. For whatever good THAT does

them; let&#39;s face it, a Hideo Kojima character 
with a full range of emotion is like a dog at the

controls of a riding lawnmower. Hilarious, yes, 
but it&#39;ll upset whoever maintains the flower beds.
